Award.AbstractNarration:
Emotions contribute to essentially every human behavior. We decide what to do based partly on our emotions, we learn from our emotional experiences, and we interact successfully with other people by recognizing their emotions. If we could predict emotional responses accurately, it would have implications for a broad array of domains, ranging across (but not limited to) close relationships, education, parenting, business management, consumer behavior, work performance, health behaviors, conflict resolution, and negotiations. Unfortunately, so far we cannot predict emotions accurately, mostly because they emerge in complex ways across time and involve multiple changes across short time spans, including subjective experience (e.g., feeling angry), behavior (e.g., frowning, hitting someone), and physiology (e.g., blood pressure, heart rate). In addition, most strong emotions occur during social interactions, making it necessary to simultaneously predict the emotions of all the people involved. Dr. Emily Butler (University of Arizona) and her colleagues refer to these multi-person emotion systems as "Temporal Interpersonal Emotion Systems (TIES)."

Social psychologists have developed sophisticated theories about how TIES operate, but using those theories to predict actual behavior has been thwarted by a lack of mathematical modeling expertise. This research brings together expertise in TIES and Bayesian modeling, which is a powerful mathematical approach for predicting the behavior of complex systems. For example, Bayesian modeling has been used successfully for problems as diverse as weather prediction, controlling missiles, and detecting credit card fraud, but has rarely been applied to human emotional processes. Bayesian methods and existing data from three prior studies will be used to predict health behaviors and outcomes (e.g., weight gain, cancer recovery) from interpersonal emotional processes in the context of adult romantic relationships. To ensure broad impact, the iPlant collaborative, a large NSF funded project to create shared computational infrastructure for 2020 science, will provide computational capability in the form of web services, whereby researchers choose TIES models, submit data, fit models using software running on a super-computer, and retrieve results over the web. By providing support to other research groups to make their models available through iPlant, a wide range of powerful TIES models will become available, broader web dissemination will be achieved, and it will become easier to compare models and methods. The results of this work will inform family-level health-promotion interventions. More broadly, the larger goal is to foster cumulative research that supports pragmatic applications. Information about TIES is important for developing parenting classes, family counseling programs, interventions for health behaviors, managerial and negotiation training, reducing bullying in schools, and promoting constructive international relations. Together these efforts will provide the broad scientific base needed for transforming theoretical knowledge of TIES into pragmatic applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If we could predict emotions during social interactions we could intervene in a broad array of domains ranging across marital quality, education, parenting, health behaviors, work performance, and political negotiations. One major challenge is that emotions unfold in complex ways over time, both within individuals and between people who are interacting with each other. Developing and testing theories about interpersonal emotional processes therefore requires mathematical models that can represent such complexity. The objectives of our project were to: 1) bring generative statistical modeling, as used by researchers in computational intelligence, to social psychology in order to develop, evaluate, and disseminate powerful models for interpersonal emotions, 2) apply the models to answer outstanding questions about emotional processes and health, and 3) to provide computational capability for other researchers so that they can use the models we develop in their own research.

Our project largely accomplished our goals. We have developed and tested a set of dynamic systems models that can be used to answer questions about the causes and consequences of different emotional processes during social interactions. We have used the models in several studies to investigate connections between interpersonal emotions and health. In one example, we found that different emotional patterns in romantic couples were associated with body weight, with overweight couples showing volatile, poorly regulated emotions when discussing health-relevant lifestyle decisions. These results suggest that interpersonal emotional processes may undermine attempts to engage in a healthier lifestyle. In a second example, we found that over-time dynamic correlations between inflammatory immune markers and sickness symptoms were attenuated in breast cancer survivors who had high levels of emotional acceptance. These results suggest that targeting emotion regulation may help to break the cycle between inflammation and sickness symptoms in women with breast cancer.

Both our methodological innovations and our substantive findings have been disseminated in a number of journal publications, invited book chapters and presentations at professional conferences and workshops. In addition, in order to stimulate inter-disciplinary collaboration we hosted an international workshop focused on computationally intensive methods for investigating emotions during social interactions.  The workshop was attended by 65 people from the U.S., Canada, and Europe and generated several special journal issues, edited books and a follow-up workshop held in Ireland. Finally, we are working on two computer interfaces that will allow other researchers to use our models. Several research groups have been helping us to test these and others are keen to do so as soon as we can support broader usage. We expect wide-spread use of our tools, with accompanying broad impact across computational social psychology, once we achieve our final goal of providing a robust and friendly user-interface.
